body:
Should just be:

``` js
const screenfull = require('screenfull');
```

The `main` entry is defined to be the dist.
`onClick()` should probably be on a newline to make it clearer the above is a decorator.
I would go with `toggleScreenfull`=>`toggleFullscreen` here as it's more readable.
I believe that's how the Angular Style Guide use attribute decorators: https://angular.io/styleguide#!#06-01

```js
var document = window && typeof window.document !== 'undefined' ? window.document : {};
```

Amended.
Uh, what's this? `document` doesn't have an `off` method. Does this run for you?
Uh indeed... Fixed in 3.3.1
Don't generate the dist files. This is only done before a release.
This line should be `elem[request](keyboardAllowed ? Element.ALLOW_KEYBOARD_INPUT : {});` because of https://github.com/sindresorhus/screenfull.js/pull/111
Awesome! Thanks for the catch!
`Boolean` is moot here.
This fix is also not correct. The promise will never resolve if this statement is true.

yeah, actually, I just get rid of the `Boolean`, because since the `fullScreenElement` function return `null` in case of falsy value. I fixed the thing, I think :)

> The built code should not be included. The code is built on new versions only.

Yes, sure, my bad.
This is still not correct. When in fullscreen and exciting, the promise will resolve before it's actually excited.
Oh yes, it's returning a promise, should be fixed now.
Returning `resolve()` makes no sense.
You should not rely on this being a promise as it's not true for all browsers. Your logic below also makes no sense when you do that as you're essentially doing the same thing twice.
This makes no sense. You're catching the error and then just throwing it again.

diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,86 @@
+export type RawEventNames = Readonly<{
+	requestFullscreen: string;
+	exitFullscreen: string;
+	fullscreenElement: string;
+	fullscreenEnabled: string;
+	fullscreenchange: string;
+	fullscreenerror: string;
+}>;
+
+export type EventName = 'change' | 'error';
+
+export interface Screenfull {
+	/**
+	 * A boolean whether fullscreen is active.
+	 */
+	readonly isFullscreen: boolean;
+
+	/**
+	 * The element currently in fullscreen, otherwise `null`.
+	 */
+	readonly element: Element | null;
+
+	/**
+	 * A boolean whether you are allowed to enter fullscreen. If your page is inside an `<iframe>` you will need to add a `allowfullscreen` attribute (+ `webkitallowfullscreen` and `mozallowfullscreen`).
+	 */
+	readonly enabled: boolean;
+
+	/**
+	 * Exposes the raw properties (prefixed if needed) used internally.
+	 */
+	raw: RawEventNames;
+
+	/**
+	 * Make an element fullscreen.
+	 *
+	 * If your page is inside an `<iframe>` you will need to add a `allowfullscreen` attribute (+ `webkitallowfullscreen` and `mozallowfullscreen`).
+	 *
+	 * Keep in mind that the browser will only enter fullscreen when initiated by user events like click, touch, key.
+	 *
+	 * @param element - Default is `<html>`. If called with another element than the currently active, it will switch to that if it's a decendant.
+	 * @returns A promise that resolves after the element enters fullscreen.
+	 */
+	request(element?: Element): Promise<void>;
+
+	/**
+	 * Brings you out of fullscreen.
+	 *
+	 * @returns A promise that resolves after the element exits fullscreen.
+	 */
+	exit(): Promise<void>;
+
+	/**
+	 * Requests fullscreen if not active, otherwise exits.
+	 *
+	 * @returns A promise that resolves after the element enters/exits fullscreen.
+	 */
+	toggle(element?: Element): Promise<void>;
+
+	/**
+	 * Add a listener for when the browser switches in and out of fullscreen or when there is an error.
+	 */
+	on(name: EventName, handler: (event: Event) => void): void;
+
+	/**
+	 * Remove a previously registered event listener.
+	 */
+	off(name: EventName, handler: (event: Event) => void): void;
+
+	/**
+	 * Alias for `.on('change', function)`.
+	 */
+	onchange(handler: (event: Event) => void): void;
+
+	/**
+	 * Alias for `.on('error', function)`.
+	 */
+	onerror(handler: (event: Event) => void): void;
+}
+
+/**
+ * Simple wrapper for cross-browser usage of the JavaScript [Fullscreen API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en/DOM/Using_full-screen_mode), which lets you bring the page or any element into fullscreen. Smoothens out the browser implementation differences, so you don't have to.
+ */
+declare const screenfull: Screenfull | false;
+
+export default screenfull;
+export as namespace screenfull;
body: Why is this needed? We already export the `Screenfull` namespace.
